title: Native apps go binding - Smart contract deployment shows success status but storage not updated

body: I notice you are using a very old version `1.8.12`. Could you please upgrade your code version to `1.9.0` since we already improve the `go binding` a bit.

hey @bansatya , I wrote the guide you were following. could you email me at zed@shootbird.work? kauri is under maintenance at the moment, and last i checked i couldn't see a "reply" button in the comments section. would also help if i could clone a repository of what you were doing because it's hard to tell what goes where in the code you've pasted. thanks!

@bansatya I just tested your contract with this code snippet https://gist.github.com/rjl493456442/979fa456149b4ffe8a51ca743df5b8b1, all functions work well.

And also from your log: `contract creation code storage out of gas`, it means your contract hasn't been deployed(out-of-gas). If you are running in a private network, you have to check 
* the gas specified by contract creation transaction
* the block gas limit
to ensure there is enough gas to deploy the contract.

@bansatya that was what i thought too. it's likely that you're using the Geth gas oracle (as per the guide) by specifying the following fields in your `bind.TransactOpts` :

```
&bind.TransactOpts{
  GasPrice: nil,
  GasLimit: 0,
}
```

I decided not to tweak these values and just use the gas oracle as prescribed by the Geth godoc, but if you're running into issues, you can adjust these values according to how much gas you're willing to spend.

see also:

- https://godoc.org/github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/accounts/abi/bind#TransactOpts
- https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/wiki/Gas-Price-Oracle

Thanks @rjl493456442 . I will check that

@zeddee , I tried  by setting the gas amount. Now , there is no error in Ethereum console. But having same issue in the contract.

**Code snippet changes:**

return quiz.QuizSession{
       // TransactOpts: *auth,
        TransactOpts: bind.TransactOpts{
                From:     auth.From,
                Signer:   auth.Signer,
                GasLimit: 4700000,
                GasPrice: big.NewInt(1000000),
        },

@bansatya i think the issue is not likely to be a problem with Geth (e.g. if the contract bin generated by remix and the bin generated for go bindings differ, that sounds more like a solidity-related issue), so i propose we take the issue offline? Ping me at zed@shootbird.work and I'll help in whatever way I can.

Also, it's difficult for me to do anything with the information you're posting up e.g. I can't read hex; they're just small facets of what's going on. I'll be able to help you better if you put up a repository of the code you're trying to run so I can test and debug it on my end. Thanks!

@bansatya The generated code is different because solidity compiler will add some metadata into the bytecode. https://solidity.readthedocs.io/en/latest/metadata.html

The remix will add some source code path prefix so the "swarm hash" is different.

Though the smart contract byte code(deployed) is same in both the network (Also transaction status is success), while fetching the data or sending transaction it fails. Any idea why the behavior is different?

**Note:** there is no error in Geth log.

@bansatya please tell us what command/application you're using to run your private local geth node. it doesn't matter what i run on my own machine if we don't know what you're doing â€” we're just creating more variables to test.
my suspicion is that your local dev node is not mining itself, so no txs can be confirmed and therefore no data is on the chain.

@bansatya to answer your question: yes, i've run your repo on a local dev node, and it works.

Here's my startup (docker) script:

```bash
docker run --rm -ti \
  -p 8545:8545 -p 30303:30303 \
  -v $(pwd):/root/.ethereum \
  -v $(pwd)/tmp:/tmp \
  ethereum/client-go:alltools-release-1.9 \
  geth --dev --dev.period 15 \
  --rpc \
  --rpcapi="eth,net,web3,admin,personal" \
  --rpcaddr="0.0.0.0" \
  console 2>>eth.log \
```

you also cannot compare the deployed bytecode a **solidity compiled** contract (a `bin` file that you can generate a json interface `abi` file for) to the bytecode deployed via web3 using a json interface object. 

i'm not too familiar with how each compiles down to EVM bytecode, but i would not expect them to be the same, just as i cannot expect the _same_ contract implemented in solidity v.s. vyper to compile down to exactly the same bytecode.
@zeddee ,  I am fine with different byte code. But why the behavior is different in two cases?

@bansatya Youâ€™re comparing two different APIs.

Well, Here are the script.

**init script:**

rm -rf node1/datadir/geth
rm -rf node1/datadir/geth.ipc
rm -rf node1/datadir/history

rm -rf node2/datadir/geth
rm -rf node2/datadir/geth.ipc
rm -rf node2/datadir/history

geth --nousb --datadir node1/datadir init node1/genesis.json
sleep 5
geth --nousb --datadir node2/datadir init node3/genesis.json
sleep 5

echo "Initialization complete. Run start.sh to start geth"

**start script**

nohup geth --datadir "node1/datadir" --identity "node1" --networkid 777 --unlock 0 --password node1/password --allow-insecure-unlock --rpc --rpcport 4585 --rpccorsdomain "*" --rpcaddr 0.0.0.0 --rpcapi "eth,web3,net,admin,miner,personal" --port 22017 --verbosity 5 --nodiscover &

sleep 5

nohup geth --datadir "node2/datadir" --identity "node2" --networkid 777 --unlock 0 --password node2/password --allow-insecure-unlock --rpc --rpcport 4586 --rpccorsdomain "*" --rpcaddr 0.0.0.0 --rpcapi "eth,web3,net,admin,miner,personal" --port 22018 --verbosity 1 --nodiscover &

sleep 5

@bansatya I'm assuming that you've started the miner on either nodes, or set up another node to mine. To narrow down the issue further, can you run a local dev node with this command and run your DApp against it?:

```bash
geth --dev --dev.period 5  --rpc --rpcapi="eth,net,web3,admin,personal" --rpcaddr="0.0.0.0"  --rpcport 8545 console 2>>eth.log
```
This is a simpler single private node using PoA that preloads a dev account with eth. The keystore can be found in `/tmp`.

If running `geth --dev` works (as it does on my machine), we know that it's probably an issue with your environment (since hitting the rinkeby endpoint also works on your machine).
@zeddee. Thanks for your explanation. I think, you are not getting the issue I pointed here. Let me know if you need any other information.

@zeddee , I verified in POA and seems working as you confirmed.

I am not sure why the issue is coming with PoW. I will check it in another network with Pow.
